title: Davi Moreira
text:
Welcome!
I am a Clinical Assistant Professor in the Quantitative Methods Department at the Mitch Daniels School of Business, Purdue University. Before this, I held several academic positions, including Visiting Assistant Professor positions at the Quantitative Theory and Methods Department at Emory University and the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. I also served as an Assistant Professor in the Political Science Department at the Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPE) in Brazil. In 2017, I was honored with the Best Brazilian Ph.D. Dissertation Prize in Political Science and International Relations.
My research and teaching interests focus on applied Data Science, Text as Data, NLP, Predictive Analytics, and Artificial Intelligence.

text:
Turning Data Into Impact
I’m pleased to share an inspiring story about the transformative impact of experiential learning projects I mentored at Purdue University’s Daniels School of Business this Spring Semester in 2025. This feature highlights how my students have successfully leveraged their data science and analytical skills to support nonprofit organizations, such as Indy Reads and Girl Scouts of Central Indiana. Through these collaborative projects, our students not only gained valuable real-world experience but also made meaningful contributions by improving operational efficiency and decision-making capabilities for these community-focused organizations. You can read more about this enriching collaboration and its positive outcomes here.


Transforming Nonprofits, Empowering Students
This piece shares a feature from Purdue University’s Daniels School of Business that highlights the impactful collaboration between our students and nonprofit organizations through the Krenicki Center for Business Analytics and Machine Learning’s Community Impact Initiative during the 2025 Spring Semester. This initiative exemplifies how experiential learning can simultaneously empower students and strengthen community organizations. In this article, you’ll find insights into how student teams mentored by me applied data analytics to address real-world challenges faced by nonprofits, enhancing their operational efficiency and strategic decision-making. As a faculty mentor, I had the privilege of guiding these students as they developed practical solutions that not only enriched their educational experience but also delivered tangible benefits to our community partners. You can read more about this collaborative effort here.

Nunca é tarde…
Não fui muito produtivo na iniciativa do blog, mas no ano de 2017 pude publicar sobre um pouco do que estive desenvolvendo nos projetos do Banco Mundial em Moçambique, segue link:
https://blogs.worldbank.org/opendata/improving-how-we-measure-progress-community-biodiversity-conservation-projects-mozambique


Iniciando os trabalhos
Faz tempo que desejo começar um blog. Como todos que trabalham com estatística e programação, por vezes fui beneficiado pelo trabalho de desconhecidos que publicaram seus códigos e suas ideias na rede. É este o principal objetivo deste espaço.
Para ser produtivo, desde já indico que não serei purista nas minhas publicações. Não vou ficar revisando meu código ou meu texto para publicar. Assim que tiver algo que possa ser útil para alguém, vou fazer questão de publicá-lo, mesmo sem a devida revisão e rigor que esta atividade pode merecer. Peço desculpas por isso, mas para contribuir ao máximo com as ideias e o conteúdo da rede, vou adotar a estratégia de que o ótimo é inimigo do bom! Me perdoem pelos possíveis erros que possa cometer.
Tudo o que for publicado pode ser utilizado de forma livre e gratuita. Peço a gentileza de citarem a fonte quando puderem e estarei aberto a quaisquer comentários. Na medida do possível – hoje faço doutorado e trabalho no mínimo 40 horas semanais -, vou me esforçar para responder a todas as indagações. No entanto, é importante deixar claro que este será mais um espaço de publicação do que de debate.
De forma secundária, este blog será feito para mim mesmo. Desejo manter o registro de coisas que considero importantes para a minha vida e minha atividade profissional.
A princípio as publicações estarão em português, mas pode ser que eventualmente eu faça alguma coisa na língua inglesa. Recomendo a todos os seres deste planeta que aprendam essa língua como meio para maximizar sua existência. O inglês não só se tornou a língua da Ciência contemporânea, como compõe a maior parte do conteúdo publicado na internet.
É isso aí, vamos colocar a mão na massa!

title: Applied Projects
text:
2015




Verbo ao Voto

It is a product of the UFPE’s Computational and Experimental Political Science Lab (@cpcex_lab)developed to portray the 2022 Brazilian Presidential election. The project’s objective is to provide journalists, marketers, political analysts, political advisors, the candidates themselves, and Brazilian society with summary and updated information on the electoral dispute. The project was developed in collaboration with Mônica Rocabado and Antonio Pires.




reeLegis

reeLegis is a product of the UFPE’s Computational and Experimental Political Science Lab (@cpcex_lab). The platform allows comparing the performance of parliamentarians seeking reelection. Using the Structural Topic Model (STM) algorithm, we analyzed more than 30k proposals presented by all federal deputies who acted between 2019 and 2022. The results show topics prioritized by reelection candidates during their mandates. It was developed in collaboration with Renata Cavalcanti and Bhreno Vieira.




Retórica Parlamentar

Web application developed during the first Hackathon of the Brazilian Chamber of Deputies in 2013. I was responsible to develop a web crawler to obtain all Brazilian deputies’ speeches and to analyze more than 14.000 speeches using advanced statistical techniques. The result shows 70 topics emphasized by over 400 parliamentarians between February 2011 and October 2013.

title: Experiential Learning
section: Krenicki Center for Business Analytics & Machine Learning at Purdue University
text:
Krenicki Center for Business Analytics & Machine Learning at Purdue University

Girl Scouts Project



Project team: Rishita Korapati, Gabriel Morales, and Ramya Polineni.


This initiative enhances cookie sales forecasting for the Girl Scouts of Central Indiana by advancing their predictive methods beyond the current naive approach, which relies solely on prior-year data and explains about 70% of sales variability. By utilizing advanced time series forecasting techniques applied to comprehensive data from 1,000 troops collected over five years, I mentored the student to develop a more complex predictive model and incorporate critical factors such as troop participation rates, regional market dynamics, and seasonal fluctuations. This refined approach yields superior predictive accuracy exceeding 80%, significantly improving inventory management by reducing surplus and optimizing sales opportunities. The resulting analytical framework not only improves immediate decision-making and fundraising effectiveness but also provides a foundation for future organizational advancements in forecasting and resource allocation.


Indy Reads Project



Project team: Rohan Ajay, Parth Kapila and Harsh Srivastava.


In this project, I mentored students that collaborated with Indy Reads to enhance the organization’s enrollment process by identifying inefficiencies and integrating current data sources. The project aimed to reduce manual data entry and create a more streamlined experience for applicants, staff, and volunteers. By reviewing the existing process—spanning Form Assembly, Salesforce, SharePoint, Calendly, and InTERS—the team ensured seamless data flow across all systems. Implementing simple automations, the students improved operational efficiency, boosted responsiveness for applicants, and significantly lowered staff workload.
